title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: Elephants gesture to signal what they want—just like us
items.description: New experiments show elephants use a wide range of movements to express their desires

items.title: Some butterflies adapted to have second ‘heads’ that confuse predators
items.description: A new evolutionary analysis of butterflies finds “false heads” arose from the coalescence of multiple traits

items.title: AI challenge to find lost Amazonian civilizations draws critics
items.description: Scientists, ethicists, and officials worry the OpenAI-sponsored contest sidesteps archaeological norms

items.title: Democrats stage a science fair of canceled grants to show what’s been lost
items.description: Partisan fight over Trump cuts heats up as Congress works on 2026 spending bills.

items.title: ‘It’s a nightmare.’ U.S. funding cuts threaten academic science jobs at all levels
items.description: “There is a lot of pressure to essentially leave the country or not pursue research,” one Ph.D. student says

items.title: Comprehensive look at U.S. children’s health finds ‘steady decline’
items.description: U.S. children are more likely to die than those in other high-income countries, a new analysis confirms

items.title: Vampire bats’ mutual grooming helps spread innovative rabies vaccine
items.description: A gel that bats lick off one another’s fur could help prevent rabies outbreaks in cattle, a growing problem in Latin America

items.title: Journal plagued with problematic papers, likely from paper mills, pauses submissions
items.description: The halt will let Taylor &Francis focus on checking Bioengineered’s papers for fraudulent works and paid authorships

items.title: NIH restores grants to South Africa scientists, adds funding option for other halted foreign projects
items.description: A policy tweak to the ban on foreign “subawards” should allow clinical trials worldwide to continue

items.title: Ancient wooden tools show human ancestors ate their veggies
items.description: Found in China, 300,000-year-old digging sticks reveal a lost technology
